Find the $3 \times 3$ matrix $\mathbf{M}$ such that
\[\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} y \\ z \\ x + y + z \end{pmatrix}\]for all real numbers $x,$ $y,$ and $z.$
ground_truth:
Let $\mathbf{r}_1,$ $\mathbf{r}_2,$ $\mathbf{r}_3$ be the row vectors of $\mathbf{M},$ and let $\mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix},$ so
\[\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -\mathbf{r}_1- \\ -\mathbf{r}_2- \\ -\mathbf{r}_3- \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} \mathbf{r}_1 \cdot \mathbf{v} \\ \mathbf{r}_2 \cdot \mathbf{v} \\ \mathbf{r}_3 \cdot \mathbf{v} \end{pmatrix}.\]We want $\mathbf{r}_1 \cdot \mathbf{v} = y.$  Thus, we can take $\mathbf{r}_1 = (0,1,0).$

Also, we want $\mathbf{r}_2 \cdot \mathbf{v} = z.$  Thus, we can take $\mathbf{r}_2 = (0,0,1).$

Finally, we want $\mathbf{r}_3 \cdot \mathbf{v} = x + y + z.$  Thus, we can take $\mathbf{r}_3 = (1,1,1).$  Hence,
\[\mathbf{M} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
